title: Hands down best movie to ever exist
text:
The phrase "life is like a box of chocolates" is extremely misleading. While it is true that you never know what will be inside that box, the contents of a chocolate box are always good, unlike life. If you live a life like anyone but Forrest Gump, life is actually like a box of those jelly beans that are either tasty flavors such as lime or strawberry banana, or disgusting ones like grass clippings or rotten eggs. Forrest Gump, played by Tom Hanks in Forrest Gump, stumbles through life aimlessly and ends up being one of the most successful men on the planet. Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump is one of the most iconic movies and should serve as the model for how a film should be made. Its wonderful storytelling, advanced special effects, and valuable life lessons raises the movie to a level that only a select few have eclipsed.
 Zemeckis brilliantly tells the story of Forrest's life through a series of flashbacks. The plot is intriguing by itself, but the flashbacks add a unique spin to the movie. Forrest is first introduced as a middle aged man sitting at a bus stop adorning a pair of extremely worn out shoes holding a suitcase and a box of chocolates. Although some might argue that the use of flashbacks is unnecessary, the audience receives a lot of insight about Forrest's life by telling the story through flashbacks. Forrest effectively serves as a narrator and is able to tell the audience what he was thinking and what resulted from his actions. By delivering the story in flashbacks, Forrest is also able to provide comedic relief throughout the movie. From moments when he explains how he was named after the founder of the KKK, to how he inspired Elvis Presley's dancing or even he is reminiscing about visiting the White House, the movie provides an effective amount of comedy in order to maintain its seriousness. Forrest's narration also provides a seamless transition between various flashbacks. This, combined with the fact that the plot of the story is based off of what actually happened in real life, makes for impeccable storytelling. By having the plot revolve around events like the Vietnam War and multiple presidencies, the viewers who grew up or lived during these times can easily recollect their experiences. The powerful storytelling combined with amazing special effects makes Forrest Gump one of the most memorable films.
 The special effects team demonstrates their mastery throughout the duration of the movie. Forrest is embedded into numerous video clips that display monumental moments in history and include some of the most iconic figures of the 60s and 70s. Forrest can be seen shaking hands with John F. Kennedy, showing his gun shot wound to Lyndon Johnson, and discovering the Watergate scandal during Richard Nixon's presidency. He also appears on a TV show with John Lennon. These edited videos provide laughs for the entire audience in addition to making the film very memorable by relating Forrest's life to what actually happened in real life. The editors and producers don't only excel in planting Forrest in the middle of history changing moments, but demonstrate their excellence while depicting events of the Vietnam war. The movie is able to accurately portray the scene in Vietnam with huge explosions and gunfire, as well as adding in rain that goes sideways or even seems like it's rising up. The scenes of the war are able to show men getting blown up, bleeding out, and losing their limbs. The effects team was also able to demonstrate their ability while creating the very first scene of the movie. The screen opens up and follows a feather making abrupt movements, wandering about in the air. Although it may sound simple, complicated movements in the background are also completed, and the entire surrounding area is painted by following the feather around. The scene also provides a brilliant metaphor for Forrest's life. Like a feather, Forrest goes through life without a care in the world for his future actions but makes it through without any harm. The movie is told with brilliant storytelling and visual imagery(don't forget about the top-notch soundtrack too), but is set apart by its valuable lessons.
 Forrest Gump is one of the greatest teaching movies. Since Forrest has a really low IQ and comprehension of basic topics, many of the life lessons are simple and easy to understand. Even though the words of wisdom Forrest provides seem very basic, they effectively make the audience rethink their understanding life. For example, as Forrest making his famous run across the country, he tells the audience how it is necessary to get over your past before you can move forward. Even for a successful man like Forrest, he needed to get over the past tragedies of his life like losing his best friend Bubba in war, his mother dying of cancer, and losing his childhood love Jenny. The value of true friendship is also demonstrated as Forrest gives the half of the profit from his multimillion-dollar shrimping business to Bubba's family since he wanted to keep his promise of sharing the profits. Forrest's journey also teaches the audience that sometimes the best we can do is to just try our best and hope everything works out in the end. No matter what, he always supported Jenny even though she put him through a lot of emotional trauma. In the end, their childhood romance is completed as they get married and Forrest becomes a father. Forrest's adventure is filled with models for how one should live their life, like finding what you truly love and being able to do that. What got him places in the first place was running, which allowed him to go to college so he could play football. After becoming a successful player, he became a war hero due to his ability to run. One of the most important things that stemmed from his love of running was when he got famous during his trips across America, which led him back to the love of his life Jenny. Although very unrealistic, it teaches the audience that sticking through the tough times and always working hard will result in a better outcome than what you started at. Forrest's success can only be attributed to those simple lessons Forrest was taught by his mother as a kid growing up.
 The effective storytelling of Forrest's journey makes Forrest Gump of the most memorable films. Filled with comedy, drama, and action, the movie surpasses expectations for storytelling as well as the visual effects elevating the film to a higher level. The movie effectively provides support for its audience, advising them how they can get through life successfully even if they start from the back of the pack like Forrest. These three aspects are just a few of the reasons why Forrest Gump is one of the most iconic movies and why it won six Academy Awards. Even if you are not old enough to relate to the events of the film, it serves as one of the most enjoyable and iconic movies ever created. Forrest's journey provides the basis for what a movie should be, and what film directors should aspire to make.

title: Oscar?
text: Please understand that despite my summary, I did enjoy this clever film. There was a lot to like. However, little of the film seemed Oscar-worthy and it probably should not be in the IMDb top 250. I think this is a great case of a very good film that has been prematurely elevated to greatness.As far as the plot goes, with zillions of reviews on IMDb for this film, I won't even bother. The acting was very good, the special effects ranged from freakin' amazing (such as digitally removing Lt. Dan's leg--quite an achievement for 1994) to very, very poor (inexplicably, despite Forrest being expertly inserted in many scenes, the one with John Lennon was very sloppy and the seams were very, very obvious on the big screen). The negatives included a few problems with continuity (such as the happy face being supposedly invented by Gump in the late 70s--it had been around for nearly a decade already) and perhaps too much emphasis on episodes as opposed to story. Still, it's a very enjoyable film and one you can't help but like. But winning 6 Oscars?! It must have been a very, very slow year.

title: Everyone can be Forrest
text: Tom Hanks played a controversial character. After all, it is believed that if an actor plays the role of a man with 'problems with his head', then you can then wait a long time for a new role, as if he were a leper. Forest is a person who is poorly oriented in social life, or rather does not react to its signals in any way, is extremely focused on details and this is his advantage. Forest has a lot to learn. I would recommend watching this film to teenagers as well, as a preventive measure in relationships with people who are not like you. Very sobering. The era of the 60s is shown in detail, and at the same time the life of not the most popular social stratum, hippies, Vietnam veterans and the political situation in the United States itself. On the one hand, this is the pursuit of the American dream, and on the other hand, it is a subtle first-person narrative, with a lot of drama within the plot. There are many sad moments that set you up for philosophical reflection. In general, this picture can be offered for general development in order to increase the level of empathy for others. Strongly touched by the character of Lieutenant Dan, here is another story, within a story. The love line is generally the highest that I have seen. And of course, the theme of forgiveness, it runs like a through line through the whole picture. Music, script, acting and strong emotions - that's what I especially liked. Recommend.

title: life is like a box of chocolates

This is a movie about the story of a simple and remarkably humble man, Florrest. Florrest right from the start never was a kid gifted with, what society considers, "a good IQ". He was considered a dumb kid. Although everyone said, many times, "you're stupid", Florrest never seemed to care about it, he genuinely wasn't a man of ego. He never wanted a rich life or to have expensive things. Florrest unconditional followed his instinct no matter what and always did what he thought to be right. I found every little thing remarkably spontaneous and truthful... This is a poor example but the way he saw the coronal and just jumped into the water to go to him or the way he was unconditionally always thinking about Jenny or the simple way that he is sitting down in a bench telling his story to who may want to listen. He teaches us something without him even trying to. To me, my moral of it is... " life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what your gonna get".

title: My favorite movie.
text: Some people call the movie unrealistic or exploitative in using a character with mental disability for entertainment. I agree with it and still say its a damn entertaining movie. I am not American so the historical placement(of Gump) isn't really as important for me as the movie and its message(If they really did intent it) is. Except of course Forrest giving the opening verse of 'imagine' to John Lennon and giving Elvis dance tips.Now that i have the major issues with the movies out of the way. I'll try to explain why i like the movie. I can say this in one word "escapism". Yes, for me this movie is ~3 hours of unadulterated fantasy( although i am not much a fan of the fantasy genre and FG doesn't figure as a fantasy flick.) I have watched this movie several times and each time i love it even more.This a movie that is based on the script and the acting rather than on strong characters. The character of Forrest is simple enough, although Tom Hanks does bring him to life much convincingly and colorfully. The story for me is about how an obviously slow, simple and unassuming guy influences the life of so many people around with his spirit and his faith in humanity. How Forrest's childlike perspective of the world lets him ask the questions that we all would love to ask but don't dare, out of fear of appearance. Call me a sissy but i enjoy a bit of emotion and the soft stuff. I couldn't help but feel all the raw and pure emotions(unadulterated by biases) that Forrest felt when he goes through all that he goes through; War, peace, love, heartbreak. There's action, drama, romance and comedy. i cant think of any movie that touches on this many genres and pulls it off as well as this one.Like i said before this movie is based on the story and innocence of Forrest than about the characters. But still the characters like jenny, Lieutenant Dan and Mama are brought to life wonderfully by a great cast. Gary Sinise especially was great and deserved to win an Oscar for his role. One other thing that stands out is the music. Such classic songs such as the "sweet home Alabama' 'free bird'are featured with great timing. I've never seen any movie that has the right songs for the situations as this one. And the song 'Turn Turn'by The Byrds seems like it was written just for this movie, although it was recorded in 1965. Although this is my favorite movie i have some gripes with it. I think the ending(or the last half hour) was a bit bland and depressing. I Really didn't appreciate the movie going form flash-back to the present. And I couldn't but help thinking about the movie "i am Sam". I was imagining Forrest junior having to go through everything that Dakota Fanning goes through in that movie. I cant figure out how they could have made it any different. But still, its the reason i give it a 9.

title: Forrest Gump
text: Forrest Gump is a great film that shows that even though there may be a lot of obstacles if you keep a positive attitude you can make it through. They do this by having Tom Hanks, Forrest Gump, tell the story of his life and the obstacles he overcame without letting the audience know he was already very successful. Tom Hanks does a great job portraying Forrest Gump, he always seems to have a great attitude, even though Forrest goes through a lot of hardships but always seems to get lucky and make out the best, but at the same time looks like he has no idea what he is doing or what is really going on. This film shows that you can always make it through whatever you are going through.

title: my idol
text:
Mr. A Gan is a man who is short in intelligence but rich in mind! It is impossible for us to make the wildest guess at what achievements he could fulfill. History does not recount whether a man regarded as 'stupid' can do so many amazing things, but the fact is that he does gains a great deal of unexpected fame and success.
The deep impression that the movie give me is that he just keep running all the time. Mr. A Gan, it seems, has run into the university, the White House and even the whole continent. Sometimes I wonder if we all misunderstand the true meaning of smart and clever, for Mr. A Gan has taught us a very different lesson. From my point of view, kindness and simplicity is the cleverest wealth that God has given us.
But of the human beings, unpredictable Nature selected only Mr. A Gan, one wonders also why Nature, with Mr. A Gan, made it possible that people who was treated as a fool can surely make a difference. Mr. A Gan's success is no accident. There is no doubt that ordinary people like you and me can live a rich life by perseverance!

title: One of the Best Movies Ever Created! Period!
text: When the movie opens, you think it is just a regular movie. When Tom Hanks transforms into Forrest when he talks, you know the movie will be one of the best movies you have ever seen. The way the writers and director shape the way Forrest is and his encounters with JFK, John Lennon, Elvis, and LBJ, President Nixon, Watergate, and many other things. He does not know the significance on how good or important it is because he does not know how to comprehend it. That is the genius of the movie. To have a character who does not know his own significance in the since the writers put it is simply brilliant. The relationship between him and Bubba and Lt. Dan stand out and show how true friendship is supposed to be. The three endure hard times at Vietnam as Bubba dies, and Lt. loses his legs and Forrest wounded from battle. The most interesting relationship on the movie has to be between Forrest and Jenny. Forrest and Jenny are child hood friends and the relationship grows when Forrest has deeper feelings for Jenny. The feelings are not returned from Jenny because she thought Forrest deserved better than her. The relationship is one of the main topics in the movie that will hit you. The movie is really on one man's relationships with so many people in over a twenty year span. It also deals with trying to find self and true love. This is Tom Hanks best role he ever played and one of the greatest performances ever in the motion picture history. The characters are memorable and you will never forget them.

title: Fool to fool discord
text: Robert Zemeckis' film, an all-American phenomenon of 1994, not only became the highest-grossing at that time (collections in the USA alone exceeded the budget by 6 times) and was awarded six Oscars, including the main one ("Forrest Gump" beat such a rival as "Pulp Fiction"). But even now it is on the 22nd place among the most popular films at the American box office in history, and was also named 76th in a survey by the American Film Institute in 2007 regarding the best films of all time. Interestingly, the advertising campaign during the release of "Forrest Gump" was conducted in such a way that the impression was created: the director of three episodes of the fantastic super-spectacular picture "Back to the Future", again shot something unusual, extravagant, connected with time travel.The title character, a native of the southern (and in the understanding of many - obviously patriarchal and conservative) state of Alabama, really wanders all over America in the 50-80s, being, one way or another, an eyewitness to historical events in the life of the nation, literally getting into newsreel footage that captured famous political figures of the era from John Kennedy to Ronald Reagan and popular singers from Elvis Presley to John Lennon. Just these virtuoso moments in technical execution (the authors of visual effects, led by Ken Ralston, of course, received an Oscar) were spinning on TV, giving rise to the illusion that Forrest Gump is a kind of chameleon man (like Allen's Zelig), as if penetrating "forward into the past".But the predecessors of the new All American Hero, who in a moment turned out to be a cult figure of the mid-90s (even prestigious political magazines devoted several articles to the phenomenon of "gumpism", and clubs of "gumpomans" began to appear all over America), should not be considered comic or fantasy characters from other works of "baby boomers", including Zemeckis himself. Although it should be noted that Forrest Gump is, as it were, an ideal representative of this generation, an eternal child who has not changed for forty years of his life (his screen biography ends in the mid-80s), a carefree child of the nation, who was torn out of his native way and family hearth in vain.The parable rebellious "cuckoos" and philosophically wise "simple-minded" from such brilliant films as "Someone Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest" by Milos Forman (based on the novel by Ken Kesey), "Being There" by Hal Ashby (based on the book by Jerzy Kosinski) and "The World by Garp" by George Roy Hill (based on the bestseller by John Erving), still belonged to the "stormy sixties" or "bitter seventies". And even references to the obvious roll call of "Forrest Gump" with Frank Capra's social comedies, which glorified the ideals of Roosevelt's Prosperity program in the cinema of the 30s, are superficial and approximate. The Kaprov cranks, who were played by Gary Cooper and James Stewart, easily succumbed to political demagoguery and calls for prosperity, preaching love and care for "every John Doe" living in America from the screen. And with the naive and stupid Forrest Gump, who has an IQ of 75 (US schools accept children with an IQ of at least 80) and is not voluntarily involved in many major events of the third quarter of the twentieth century, all this rubbish and husk comes off like water from a goose.In the influential publication "Variety", in the first response to the not yet exalted tape, Forrest Gump was called, not without reason, a "self-imbecile" and compared with the autistic character Dustin Hoffman from "Rain Man". By the way, along the way, it should be noted the paradoxical similarity between the two paintings and how difficult they were born. "Rain Man" was going to be shot by at least five directors, because of this, the script was constantly being rewritten. And producer Wendy Finerman dreamed of making a satirical novel by Winston Groom for nine years before she found support at a major Paramount studio.Gump's "closest relatives" are precisely the flawed heroes from films created in post-Reagan times, at the turn of the 80-90s - in addition to "Rain Man" (4 Oscars), we should call "Born on the Fourth of July" (a tape about a disabled Vietnam War veteran was awarded only two Oscars, but one of them was for directing) and "The Smell of a Woman" (just for the role of a blind retired officer, the outstanding actor Al Pacino finally received his Oscar - and on the eighth attempt) . And Tom Hanks, played by a young lawyer with AIDS in Philadelphia, was awarded an Oscar for reasons of political correctness. So it is not surprising that for the second year in a row he was awarded this award for the role of the "glorious abnormal".Robert Zemeckis' painting is to a much lesser extent an art phenomenon or an example of an ethical act of the author. It is interesting as a psychological and sociological test, because Forrest Gump has become like an expression of the underlying moods of Americans who are tired of the struggle for existence, the race for prosperity and the two-century aspiration for the Great American Dream. After all, he stopped after three years of continuous running across America (from ocean to ocean), and declares to confused followers: "I'm tired." Here Kaprovsky Mr. Deeds drunkenly proclaimed the idea of "Back to Nature." And Gump, who has not grown wiser in wandering around the world, returns back to his family and from now on will raise a son more intelligent than himself. For Americans in the mid-90s, this ingenuous idea turned out to be almost a revelation. "Gumpism" definitely suited them!

title: Legendary!
text: For many, many years, or rather 23 years, the film "Forrest Gump" has been stirring the minds and hearts of fans and admirers of good cinema. On our KinoNews portal, this film is fairly included in the top 10. And strangely enough, there is not a single user review on it. We need to fix this urgently...Robert Zemeckis' film was released in 1994. It is an adaptation of the novel of the same name by Winston Groom. The picture immediately became popular. What to say? The film took first place at the box office in 1994. But "Forrest Gump" has not become outdated in the last few years. It is still being watched and reviewed by old fans and a new generation of moviegoers who have grown up over 20 years. And it pleases. The craving for the beautiful does not weaken. No technological revolutions and political games can stifle people's faith in justice, kindness and humanity.In 1995, the picture was appreciated not only by the audience, but also by professionals. 38 different awards have been received all over the world! She was nominated for 13 Oscars at once and received in fact 6 golden statuettes! And in such prestigious nominations as "Best Film", "Best special effects", "Best Adapted Screenplay". In addition, Zemeckis himself received an Oscar as "Best Director", and the incomparable Tom Hanks took home the statuette for "Best Actor". And I would be very surprised if this did not happen! There is still justice under the sun and moon. It's a pity that it doesn't always work...

title: Lt. Dan - Satan or Christ?
text: I rarely comment, but feel compelled.  By reading these comments it is clear how often people miss the point of movies.  Someone above mentioned that Gary Sinise was "the devil incarnate."  It would seem that the language of the character and his proclivity to use the Lord's name in vain offended the person.  While I appreciate that this person may dislike the film and obviously does not like profanity, I think that this person is missing the point... and this saddens me.I would challenge this person to understand first, then form a opinion later.  Withhold judgment, at least until the end of the film.  The person above let the barest surface of the language cloud their entire perspective of the movie.  What a shame.  After all, one doesn't have to like profanity to appreciate the point that artists are trying to make by using it.In this particular case, this person above, who seems to be very devout, missed the whole point of Lt. Dan.  In my attempt to voice my own interpretation of Lt. Dan, and to counter the very poorly voiced opinion that Lt. Dan is the Devil, I fear that I will introduce some spoilers below, so read with care.I hate to spell it out so plainly, but since the person above missed the point so completely, I will give my interpretation, however flawed.During the course of the film, Lt. Dan was on a very profound and religious journey.  The whole point, in my mind, of the character was to explore, it very direct terms, the concepts of faith in the aftermath of tragedy.   His use of the language, while consistent with the character, also show his inner turmoil and conflict with God.  Granted, the language is not for children, but as an adult I can appreciate that Lt. Dan's language was *supposed* to make me realize that he was at odds with God.  By being overly sensitive to the language, this person missed the payoff when Lt. Dan eventually finds God.  I, as a person of faith, found his story, in the subtext of the entire film, to be very interesting and gratifying.Great movies, like this one, have layers upon layers of themes and messages. It is what distinguishes them from the normal trash.  While you may not like the movie, you should at least do yourself the favor of being open-minded when viewing it.  Otherwise, don't bother spending your money.For example, the character of Lt. Dan, while a very fully realized character, was also a symbol of many things in the story.  While I will not say that my interpretations are the only possible ones - I believe that Lt. Dan, Jenny and Forest were all mirrors of the same character.  All three characters go on a journey during this film, all fight the same demons in some form, but all three stories come to a different resolution.  As they all "run" from their troubles, directly or indirectly, they each take a different path.  But Lt. Dan's path is that of religious redemption.  To call him the "devil incarnate" and treat him like a blasphemer is to deny the entire idea of redemption and forgiveness.Lt. Dan was an obvious symbol of post-Vietnam America.  He suffered physical wounds like we each suffered psychological wounds.  And I can still visualize his final confrontation with God.  I would like to ask the person above whether they even considered that, high atop the cross-timbers of a wooden mast, with his arms outstretched, his beard and hair whipping in the wind, that Lt. Dan looked quite Christ-like.  He called out into the void, and, as Forest observed, God came to him.  After finding God in the storm, Gary is given his peace, tames his demons, and is even eventually given his legs back.  A cured body to match his cured soul.I wonder if the person above thinks any of this symbolism to be an accident, or a message of the film.  Frankly, I doubt this person even thought twice about it, which is what I find sad.  But if they had, I wonder if they would have had the same negative reaction to the film.Oh well. Monkey

title: Another reason why I don't like Robert Zemeckis
text: Despite the 8.7 average rating on IMDb, the many praising reviews it receives and the good opinions of my friends, I wasn't really expecting this film to be anything special. However as it is such a highly regarded film, I thought it was probably worth watching, even if I wasn't going to enjoy it. Why I knew I wasn't going to enjoy it; it won six ocars but other films that were also released that year have since become more well loved (e.g. pulp fiction, the shawshank redemption), I'm not a really big fan of Tom Hanks as an actor (shock horror!) and Robert Zemeckis is definitely my least favourite director, creating films that (in my opinion anyway) have no real aim other than to make some cash. So how did it compare to my pre-judgements? Just as I thought really. There were many problems I found in this movie; to start with the camera angles and the camera movement made the film hard to look at visually, as the people and object moving looked very unnatural. Another problem is that aside from Forrest, all of the characters seem one dimensional as they were all extremely underwritten. Leading on from that, for me, the script is a major problem; the dialogue is incredibly tedious, every line made me sigh with frustration, but that isn't the main problem with the dialogue; I watched the film with friends and every few seconds I heard them laughing at the things Forrest says, however that's something I couldn't get into, I felt that there is something very malicious about laughing at a man with some kind of mental handicap. Though the dialogue isn't the only problem with the script, the whole story is beyond unrealistic. Although it isn't unlikely for someone to drift through life and for things to just happen to them, it is unlikely for the majority of them to be such good and life changing things, especially for a man with a mental disability, from a non-privileged background, at this time period. I also find it a little bit sneaky that they never mention what is wrong with Forrest, it seems to be they did this so they could include some parts of the plot, for example him having sex with Jenny and they her having a child, that I doubt would happen in real life to people in his condition. However, none of this is exactly enraging for me, the only thing that really makes my blood boil, is the Vietnam sequence. Films that have been made about the Vietnam war have been made with the soul purpose to let audiences know, that war is hell and war will destroy you, but Forrest's narration tells us that his experience in Vietnam was fun, which goes against everything films like Platoon, The Deer Hunter, Full Metal Jacket and Apocalypse Now stand for and aside from a few seconds of footage, nothing shows the horrors of the war, it's unrealistic and highly insulting to the people who fought in the war. Though as I have given it 3/10, there obviously must be a few plus points, there are about three. The effects that put Forrest in with archive footage and very well done and well edited, Gary Sinise is very good in an underwritten part, the fact he didn't win an Oscar is a travesty and there are some huggable children in it. Though that doesn't make up for the obvious flaws in this movie.

title: A Masterpiece, Simply and Sweetly
text: [WARNING: MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS.] I don't know what the critics might think. Call it a baffoonery if you will. I loved this movie to no end. It is a perfect, -perfect- example of a movie-making masterpiece, and deserves every bit of praise it has, and then some. The scene where Lieutenant Dan Taylor is fighting the hurricane, is showing that man can triumph, even when, and literally in this case, life cuts your legs out from under you. The reason I love this movie so much is not just because of it's wonderful figuratisms and outstanding symbolism, but because of it's un-opinionated view on American life from 1950 to 1985. It shows a man, who yes, may be a little slow, that sees the world for what it is and takes everything literally, without watering it down or making it seem better than it really is. He takes everything in, and usually through one word, or on occasion, a long speech, sums everything up, and makes everyone understand it the way he understands it. In conclusion, the critics can keep their petty under-scored "reviews" to themselves. I loved the movie, and would recommend it to -any- person who loves good movies.

title: The greatest biopic in my mind
text: There is no doubt that it is a great movie. I love this movie so much, every scene is so classic. I have seen Forrest Gump many times, but every time I see this movie, it always gives me hope and strength. With the beautiful and classic piano music in the opening section, a light feather flies in the air, floats over the roof, floats over the crowd, floats over the street, and finally falls at the feet of Forrest Gump, which seems to tell us the whole life of Forrest Gump.That feather fluttering in the wind, foreshadowed the dramatic and legendary life of Forrest Gump. Forrest Gump picked up the feather, put it in the suitcase, began to tell his life. Forrest Gump's growth up experience is half of American history, involving the Ku Klux Klan, race issues, Vietnam War, JFK assassination, Ping-pong diplomacy, Watergate affair, the rise of popular logo and so on. When Elvis Presley lived in Forrest Gump's house, he borrowed Forrest Gump's dance moves and made his rock music career. Forrest Gump meets the love of his life when he takes his first school bus ride. When he was chased and beaten, he ran as fast as he could, broke free from his leg braces, and so he ran across the road, across the field, and into the university. Forrest Gump's IQ is lower than that of normal people, but he is honest, simple, and steadfast in doing things right now. He is serious and persistent about family love and friendship, which makes him step by step to a height that is beyond the reach of normal people. After graduating, Forrest joined the Vietnam War. In Vietnam, he met Lieutenant Dan Taylor and Bubba who imaged his whole life. Returning to the United States from the Vietnam War, Forrest became a hero and promoted ping-pong diplomacy. Forrest Gump becomes the captain of a shrimping boat and inconceivably becomes the owner of the Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation with Lieutenant Dan. When Forrest Gump got the news of his mother's illness, he jumped into the water regardless of his personal danger. When Forrest Gump sat down by his mother's bed, his mother told him about her view of the meaning of life. Life was like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're going to get. You have to do the best with what God gave you. You're going to have to figure your destiny out for yourself. After Jenny left without saying goodbye, Forrest Gump began to run non-stop for no reason at all. He crossed the United States four times, which gave him a lot of followers and gave many people hope. Forrest Gump meets Jenny again and learns that he has a son. Forrest Gump married Jenny and spent the last days of her life with Jenny. Forrest Gump placed Jenny's grave under the tree where they played when they were children. I don't know if we each have a destiny, or if we're all just floating around accidental-like on a breeze, but I think maybe it's both. Maybe both get happening at the same time.

title: A movie with abundance of surprising treats, sometimes sweet and sometimes bitter.
text: Forrest Gump is a beautiful movie directed by Robert Zemeckis, starring Tom Hanks (as Forrest Gump), Robin Wright (as Jenny Curran) and screenplay written by Eric Roth that not only informs the audience and the people who interact with Forrest Gump (played by Tom Hanks) about the life, but also teaches us morals and the way life is perceived in a beautiful mind of a simple man. This movie shows the journey of a man Forrest Gump who despite having a low IQ of seventy-five, found himself in the middle of key historical events. We see Forrest Gump, throughout the movie narrates the story while he was sitting at the bus stop telling the people who sit next to him about his past experiences in his life which is the storyline and setup of the movie.The movie (Forrest Gump) is set in the 1950s-1980s in Forrest's hometown, Greenhow, Alabama. This movie can be portrayed in many different styles of films but it has mainly shown the beautiful mind of a simple man who is taken advantage of in many aspects of his life for example getting bullied by other students. In the movie he is portrayed as a simple man who achieves big things in life in ways the normal man would not achieve. We not only get emotionally connected to the main character Forrest Gump (which is played by Tom Hanks in a splendid manner), but also, we get attached to the other characters as well like mother of Forrest Gump (Mrs. Gump) played by Sally Field and Jenny Curran played by Robin Wright. The actors and actresses who were casted in the movie Forrest Gump gave justice to their roles. The director and screenplay writer played a pivotal role in properly utilizing the acting capability of the selected cast.The special effects in this movie are used uniquely and widely throughout the movie for example when Forrest meets several presidents of America and how some of them were assassinated, it makes the audience believe that Forrest was present in that time period. The emotions and reactions of the characters were shown in a beautiful way by using close ups, for example close up shot was used when young Forrest is getting his leg braces on. This close up shot will make us see and feel the pain Forrest is going through. The character development in this movie and the way the characters interact with each other is a treat to watch. There are many dialogues from the characters which stick to our memory after we finish watching the movie like "Stupid is as stupid does", "Life is like a box of chocolates you will never know what you are going to get" which makes this movie more memorable.At the end we can say this movie is also like a box of chocolates and we will never know what we are going to get next, because it has abundance of surprising treats, sometimes sweet and sometimes bitter but at the end it is one of the best movies ever made. I would like to give this movie 8.9 points out of 10 points from my side.

title: "Momma said they was my magic shoes...momma said they'd take me anywhere"
text: , Forrest Gump is the kind of guy that would take off his coat for a stranger if they were cold. The kind of person who forgives over and over and doesn't really want much in return besides friendship. He's not the smartest tool in the shed, but his love and compassion for the ones in his life go beyond what most normal people are capable of. Everyone knows he's basically the nerdy (but witty) underdog, and he is always teased or asked if he's stupid, to which he normally replies "stupid is as stupid does". He joins the army after he graduates college and meets his best good friend Bubba on the bus (a black man who is very similar in character to Forrest, and who immediately clicks with him). Bubba tells Forrest about the shrimping business, which has run in his family for at least 2 generations. They make a deal to form a "shrimping" team after they return home and split all the money 50-50. *SPOILER ALERT**DO NOT KEEP SCROLLING IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THIS MOVIE Not very long after Bubba and Gump make their pact, Bubba gets wounded in battle, as does their Lieutenant, Dan...and a couple other characters. Dan wants Forrest to leave him to get killed in battle (by bombs) because he lost his legs and he wanted to die with honor, but Forrest picked him up despite Dan's orders, and tries to save both him and Bubba, but after Bubba is carried by Forrest (also against Dan's orders), he is gasping for air and dies in Forrest's arms. I think this is one of the most important parts of the movie, because it shows not only how humble Mr. Gump is towards his friends, but his sheer backbone and determination to do the right thing. Thank you for reading

title: Simply GOAT!!!!!
text:
" You can reach everything if you only want to!""Forrest Gump" is just an epic movie that touches people throughout all ages and generations. The simplicity of this film is the main reason to love it. This is a movie of a heart-breaker of oddball wit and startling grace. There's talk of another Oscar for Tom Hanks.In a college dorm with Jenny, who lets him touch her breast, the virginal Forrest ejaculates instantly, losing her interest and his self-respect. In the Army, Forrest saves his captain (Gary Sinise), whose legs are later amputated, and the captain resents him. Forrest is everything we admire in the American character - honest, brave, loyal - and the film's fierce irony is that nobody can stay around him for long.
Zemeckis doesn't fall into the trap of using Forrest as an ad for arrested development. He knows the limits of a holy fool who can't understand the hypocrisy of postwar America that this picaresque epic so powerfully reveals. The peace-love pretensions of the '60s are skewered as neatly as the greed decades that follow. But there is something of Forrest that Zemeckis would like to see rub off on us: his capacity for hope. It's an ambitious goal in this age of rampant cynicism. Godspeed.

title: An everyman for today!
text: The movie Forrest Gump is a fantastic movie. Both setting and plot were fabulous and it definitely showed "The World". Forrest Gump starts telling how stupid he is and then he becomes a marvelous football player, a ping pong player, and shrimp fisherman. He has a different intelligence and that makes him special and so successful in life. The most inspiring thing he does is how he fights for Jenny. When he always follows her and never gives up on her. At the beginning of the film, I thought he was really stupid but I realized that all he says is symbolic. He acts stupid but is actually smarter than most of the other people, that is why you should never judge someone by his/her appearance. He also has the typical Alabama accent, which makes the movie seem even more realistic. Each character was used surrealistically and unrealistically to show the theme everyman.The actors in this movie are perfectly well cast. Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks) is such a good actor and plays his role brilliant. He should've deserved an Academic award. Sally Field, who plays Forrest's mother, is actually only 4 years older than Tom Hanks, plays her role as a mother really well and symbolizes good motherhood. She can act as if she is 20 years older than him. Jenny (Robin Wright) plays her role as a good friend of Forrest and Hippie also very well. All the main characters do their job really well in this movie. The most supporting character was Jenny (Robin Wright). She was the main reason why Forrest Gump did everything. At the end where she dies, he even mentions it that he's done everything she wanted and that he loved her. She really supported him to achieve something in his life.I really liked the setting in this movie. Where Forrest Gump starts off as a normal boy to a man in a small fictional town in Alabama, and then travels around and sees "the whole world". He is a simple Alabama kid and becomes all of a sudden really famous. It is like his life was chosen by destiny. That he would start off really small and then become very big and famous. He didn't choose to become a football player or a shrimp fisherman; he met Bubba to even find out what shrimps were. Only one thing was something he chose and always wanted to have, to get married with Jenny. His love and everything he would do for her to make her happy. The author did this on purpose. He wanted to show himself as everyman. That everyman can achieve something in their lives, not as much as Forrest Gump like he was there most of the events and became a ping pong player and all that. Obviously he couldn't be there on those events, but this is for the theme, to show everyman.When Forrest Gump started to run around the whole world, he inspired many people. Only by running he just made them all run with him. He is a great inspiration even though people think he is "dumb". He does things that seem to be stupid, but actually are very clever. He is a very hard-working man and achieves everything which everyman wants. That shows basically the theme of this movie: work hard and you will achieve your goals. No wonder that this movie had won several Academy Awards. It is a great movie and I would suggest all the people who don't believe in themselves to watch this movie. It helped me a lot to work for my dreams, my hopes, and everything what I always tried to be.If I had to rate this movie, I would give 9 out of 10 points because it has an exciting plot and well-chosen characters. Alabama is a great place for the setting of this movie and everywhere Forrest Gump went was also well chosen to show the theme: "Life is like a box of chocolates!" It means that you never know what you will get and everyman doesn't know what they get except trying to achieve their goals to find out. This movie has more than only one theme, but talking about all themes would take ages. It has got the theme of war and theme of motherhood and much more. The movie was definitely better than the book since it was more realistic and had better characterization. It is basically a message to us to see what is happening in the world or what happened. It really impressed me and I would watch it again because it is so interesting. It is almost perfect but as we all know, nothing or no one is perfect!

title: Forrest Gump Movie Review
text: "Like a box of chocolates, you'll never know what you're going to get". Like a box of chocolates, in the film, Forrest Gump, you never know what you're going to get. Directed by Robert Zemeckis in 1994, the Academy Award winning Best Picture, Forrest Gump, follows the life of main character Forrest Gump through some of his most important life events. Played brilliantly by actor Tom Hanks, audience members empathize for Forrest as they watch him overcome tremendous hardships as a handicap, growing from a mentally unstable little boy to a successful war veteran and business owner. Through heartbreak, triumph, and loss, so many elements of emotion can be felt through the movie. Also, with the events of Forrest's life very much paralleling with America's history, historical moments of our country's past can be reminisced through the film. The film's main story line with regards to American history, with the variety of elements such as comedy, drama, and romance woven together in the plot, all brought out through Tom Hanks exceptional acting, makes the movie Forrest Gump, one of the most iconic of all time.Forrest Gump's plot not only follows the story of Forrest's life, but gives a glimpse at various historical moments of America. One of the many historically significant scenes includes the The Hippie Movement and their anti-war protests, as well as the Black Panther Party, which Forrest's long time lover, Jenny, was a part of. The movie also displays what some may say is the most "accurate depiction of the Vietnam War", as Forrest, for most of his life was a veteran of the war. The Vietnam War is one of the most controversial armed conflicts to ever take place in the 20th century, and during the movie, viewers experience a realistic depiction of the "desultory", "purposelessness" of it. The historical significance that the movie encapsulates is important as it provides viewers a glimpse into the history of America through a first person point of view.The roller-coaster of emotions that are felt in the movie by various elements including comedy, drama, and romance, makes Forrest Gump an enthralling film to see. The first time I watched the film, in the beginning, I thought that the movie was just a comedy, something that would make me chuckle here and there. Little did I know that the movie contained so many lessons and morals that hit me on a deeper level. I say that the film is like a chocolate molten cake, which from the outside has the appearance of a normal, one flavored, typical sponge cake. However, delving deeper into the cake, breaking the outside, chocolate oozes out, similar to what's really under the surface of the movie, Forrest Gump. I feel like many expect the movie to just be a comedic one, but really there is so much more than that. There is romance, drama, and heartbreak, all encapsulated in one two hour span of a film. The movie's twists and turns and the various life events of Forrest are so unexpected that I found myself crying one minute and laughing hysterically the second after. You can experience so many emotions in just this one film.Without Tom Hanks' brilliant acting as Forrest Gump, the movie's inspiring story line and captivating emotional elements would not have been exhibited at its greatest potential. What was most exceptional about Hanks' acting was his ability to naturally and accurately display a slightly disabled man, a very hard task for any actor to do. There is a fine line between overly exaggerating the role of a handicap person and slipping out of the true character of one, and in my opinion, Tom Hanks perfectly maintained his character throughout the entire film. In 1995, a year after the film was released, Tom Hanks won the Academy Award for Best Actor, Golden Globe for Best Actor, Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor, and many other titles. Tom Hank's was and still is admired for his performance as Forrest, which was a tricky role to play, yet a powerful one that made the film so iconic.Without the deep rooted American culture and various elements evoking different emotions in the plot of the film, as well as Tom Hank's brilliant acting, Forrest Gump would not be the iconic movie that it is. Released in 1994, still today in 2017, Forrest Gump holds its magic and makes for one of the most iconic movies in history. Silly, heartwarming, and inspiring, Forrest Gump is an American classic that everyone should get the chance to watch.

title: A Life Lesson from an exceptional movie
text: On July 6, 1994, Paramount unveiled Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump in theaters. The Tom Hanks satire would go on to win six Oscars at the 67th Academy Awards, including best picture. The Hollywood Reporter's original review is below:Forrest Gump is not stupid. Although his IQ is 75, he sees the world far clearer than most. Through his decent, childlike eyes, we too see things in a less confused and muddled way. In this cheerfully straight-arrow moral tale, Tom Hanks stars as the "wise fool" Forrest Gump and delivers yet another Oscar-level performance. Paramount will win sensational box office with this Robert Zemeckis-directed film.Raised in the '50s in rural Alabama by a single mother (Sally Field), Forrest, being "different," must fend for himself, struggling against not only perceived expectations but boyhood bullies. He unwittingly finds that he's blessed with a talent - he can run like the wind, which wins him a football scholarship to play for Bear Bryant at the University of Alabama. And there's no stopping him after that.An uplifting saga about one young boy's earnest and good-natured attempts to overcome his disabilities, Forrest Gump is also a cheeky social satire of the past 40 years of U.S. social-political history. Eric Roth's screenplay, adapted from Winston Groom's novel, nimbly intertwines Forrest's life with the seminal social events and players of the past several decades. Unassuming Forrest, with his golly-gee enthusiasm and decency, encounters the likes of Elvis, George Wallace, presidents Kennedy through Nixon, Dick Cavett, John Lennon and Abbie Hoffman as he graduates from 'Bama, fights in Vietnam, competes in international ping-pong, founds a shrimping company, engages in philanthropy and jogs cross-country.Contrasting Forrest's unassuming innocence with the upheavals and rancor of the times, the film is a wisely goofy commentary on the stupidity of smartness.While Forrest's foray's into the dens of the big and powerful are cheekily amusing, the film ambles along over a deeper, darker layer: Forrest's love for his childhood girlfriend, Jenny (Robin Wright). An abused child, Jenny's life path is a desperate wander to find solid ground. She falls prey to every social movement and fad of the times; unlike Forrest, whose unwavering strength and sense of right and wrong protect him from being caught up in social slides, Jenny's genuflections reflect her lack of firm values and inner confidence.To some extent, one could argue that Jenny symbolizes most of us. If any criticism might be leveled at the film, it is that its most heart-wrenching moments are too adeptly skirted, but, then again, that's in keeping with Forrest's strength. Highest praise to Zemeckis, who has reached a higher maturity plane with his gracefully, technically eloquent direction.Carrying his torso in an erect, straight-arched manner, Hanks' body language is all-telling. With each strange or perplexing situation, Hanks erupts with the smallest twitch or turn, signaling Forrest's deep-seated disapproval or, in special other cases, his gleeful, thankful wonderment. Mykelti Williamson, as Forrest's simple-minded G.I. buddy, is also outstanding, while Gary Sinise is sympathetic as Forrest's bitter platoon leader, legless after the Vietnam War.

title: Christ Symbolism in FORREST GUMP
text: Lieutenant Dan: Have you found God yet, Gump?Forrest Gump: I didn't know I was supposed to be looking for him. --------------------------------I'm not the religious type. But I couldn't help notice the large amount of New Testament references in FORREST GUMP (which I assume are in the book as well). (BTW, I posted an earlier version of this to a certain progressive website, in case anyone here reads widely.)Consider: 1) Forrest was born of an earthly mother, with no indication of who his father was.2) He became a fisherman at some point in the movie. But considering the sea's ability to rehabilitate Lt. Dan, and Forest's ability to attain Lt. Dan's loyalty, I'd consider Forrest to also be a "fisher of men".3) Remember when Forrest ran and ran across the country for 3 YEARS, collecting followers along the way? Not unlike a certain religious figure.4) And when he was doing all of that running, Forrest performed various "miracles". Like inventing the smiley-face logo, and the phrase "s--t happens".5) SPOILER HERE.. By the date on her tombstone, Forrest's wife Jenny was in her early 30s when she died. Since Forrest was about the same age, we can assume he was 30 when he did his "preaching". (Strangely, Jennny - akin to Mary the Magdalene - is the one with the initials "JC" (for "Jenny Curran" according to trusty IMDb). Perhaps Dan Brown didn't quite have it right about the history of women in the early Church.)Of course, this movie is not at all "preachy", as the quote above attests to. Forrest sort of stumbles upon his situations, but he always dutifully (and sometimes cluelessly) steps up when called. The conveyance of that innocence is what really makes the movie.

title: An iconic film which must be on the watchlist of all movie buffs
text: Forrest Gump is one of the most popular movies of all time. It has a very special place in my heart. The performances are just so unforgettable and they never get out of your head. The characters, I mean the actors turned into them and that's what got to me. The lines are so memorable, touching, and sometimes hilarious.Forrest Gump(Tom Hanks) is the lead character in the film whose I.Q. is right below the average scores. But his mama(Sally Field) believes that her boy has the same opportunities as anyone else and lets Forrest know that there's nothing that could hold him back. As a boy he is put into braces for his legs since he has a crooked back and really doesn't have too many friends. When he gets on a school bus for his first day of school, NO ONE will let him sit next to them. This scene is so heart breaking until you hear a little angel's voice "You can sit here if you want". Jenny, Forrest's best friend and crush, she looks so incredibly innocent and you love her because her and Forrest are like pea's and carrots. But we find out that there is an extremely unfortunate side to her life.Forrest and Jenny together walk every day from school and when some kids start throwing rocks at Forrest calling him stupid, Jenny just tells Forrest "Run, Forrest! Run!". He miraculously breaks the braces off his legs and run like the wind blows. Forrest meets many celebrities from his life that just happened to be there: Elvis Presley visited his house before hitting it big, President Kennedy honored him with a all American football award, President Johnson who honored him with a medal of honor for his actions in Vietnam, President Nixon(in which Forrest happens to discover a problem in the Water Gate Hotel because some people seem to be flashing lights around), and John Lennon through a talk show to talk about his medal of honor.Forrest meets some interesting people along the way too that are even better than these celebrities combined; Bubba his Vietnam war friend who dreams of owning a shrimp boat one day and was born with big gums. He is just so wonderful and charming and won't stop talking about shrimp. Luteniet Dan, a leader of Forrest's army in Vietnam who gets saved by Forrest during a huge attack and looses his legs as a result. Luteniet Dan was by far my favorite character, he has so much pride and wants to die in Vietnam due to his family history tradition of dying in every single American war. He and Forrest make quite a pair. And of course there's Jenny, a very tragic figure, she gets more mean as she grows up because she knows that Forrest loves her, in some ways you can't blame her really. She was obviously abused and I think she felt that Forrest was too good for her or that he couldn't really give her the love she wanted.This movie is incredible and should be seen by everyone. "Run, Forrest! Run!" is an iconic line which still reverberates in my ears. A man can do everything in which he believes in is a lesson this film gives to us.

title: The character Forrest Gump inspires me.
text: The character Forrest Gump inspires me to push my limits and to do my best.Forrest has many limitations that would normally hold him back his whole life long. He has trouble walking and has to use leg braces and crutches. But when he has to run away from a gang of bullies, his braces unexpectedly fall away and he finds himself outrunning the bullies. This is the first time he has ever run. Forrest understands he has special abilities and that he must use them wisely. Jenny screams, "Run, Forrest, run." This admonition echoes at other crucial moments in Forrest's life. Forrest has a low IQ. He is nearly turned away from public school because his entry exam score is so much lower than that of any of the other students. He only manages to enter after his mother "befriends" the director of the school. He struggles throughout school, but to everyone's surprise, he is accepted into a famous university on an American football scholarship because he easily outruns the opposing players as he carries the football to score a touchdown. While in the army, Forrest is considered a genius by his superiors because he works well under pressure, follows orders and doesn't complain. Forrest deeply cares about the people in his life. While in the army, he constantly remembers his mom and Jenny and writes to them regularly. Another recruit in the army, a big black man named Bubba, becomes Forrest's first best friend and Forrest looks out for Bubba until the end. Forrest Gump is determined to succeed in his life despite tremendous odds. As I watch Forrest Gump struggle to overcome his limits, I feel hopeful that I, too, can overcome the obstacles that come up in my own life.

title: It taught me to run the errands of life without thinking twice.
text:
Initial release: 23 June 1994 (Los Angeles)
Director: Robert Zemeckis
Screenplay: Eric Roth
Adapted from: Forrest Gump
Awards: Academy Award for Best Picture
Forrest Gump is one of the best Hollywood movies of all time. It carries with itself the credit of 13 Academy awards and 6 Oscars. The Film is based on a true event portrayal of Vietnam war, Watergate scandal, presidencies of Johnson and Kennedy. This historic movie begins with the powerful actors and actresses, Tom Hanks as the central protagonist Forrest Bump, Robin Wright as Jenny Curran, Gary Sinise as Lieutenant Day Taylor and Sally Field as Mrs. Gump.The movie begins with the symbolism of a feather and ends thus. The movie is based on the real life history of Sammy Lee Davis. Yet the movie is half fact and half fiction. Rob Pope is the real life Forrest Gump. His running track record is 15,000 miles in the entire United States. He had covered the entire United States four times. The remarkable story line captures the historical evidence of warfare, poverty, drugs, alienation. It highlights the trilogy of determination, hard work and kindness are the key words of success.The story begins thus the prime figure Forrest Bump is born with defects in his spine, to support his crooked spine he has to wear braces to ease out his difficulty from walking. His school mate who has a prominent impact throughout his life is Jenny Curran. Her motivating words triggered an abundance of energy to Forrest. The less IQ boy moved ahead to run and covered the obstacles on his way. His determination is recognised by The President of the United States of America with the highest gallantry award. The best part of the story is its simplicity of the central hero and the portion of empathy displayed in the scenes gives a lasting effect on the viewer's psyche. The most conceptual word Love is portrayed with genuine profundity. The bond of souls is superior to physical communion. Respect the human. This strong message is vividly portrayed. The most unique part of the film is its dialogue delivery.My mama always said, 'Life was like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna get.'" - Forrest Gump
The above words are the key words of the film. The eventful moment of the movie is accepting the trade as it is. The non-complaining approach of Forrest Gump made him a celebrity. He attuned himself to every odd and came out shining. This puts a positive impact on the viewers. The movie embodies some of the elementary human vibrations such love, faith, friendship, empathy.Apart from the positive aspect of the slack characterization of Jenny, Lieutenant Day Taylor, Bubba holds the viewers with much anxiety. Their depiction of characters is in need of a strong storyline. I think this is the drawback of a powerful script. The actions of Tom Hanks, Robin Wright, Gary Sinise are notable. Of course, Tom Hanks is in his best. His total opposite character displaying in the scenes indicates his capability of holding the viewers with apt attention.According to me, I would like to give a 4.8 \5 rating to Forest Bump.This is undoubtedly a movie to be watched.

title: A True Masterpiece of Cinema
text: Forrest Gump is a lesson. A lesson that you can do whatever you want with enough patience, determination, and effort. You watch a young boy restricted by the steel of a leg brace, go from poor lows to devastating heights when he runs across the country just for the fun of it. A man who is deemed below average intelligence by his school, shake hands with the president and star on the tonight show alongside John Lennon. A man who is constantly brushed off by the love of his life, standing over her grave promising to take care of their child. A man who is bullied in school, become a war veteran earning a Medal of Honor. Seriously, the movie has everything. Romance, action, comedy, sorrow, and just about everything else you could think of. In many ways, Forrest Gump is a great life lesson as well as exciting film that has proven its worth to stand as an all time classic. If you have not seen this movie, do yourself a favor and take two and a half hours out of your day to experience a story that will likely end up somewhere amongst your favorite movies of all time. I know for sure that it is certainly my favorite!

title: A true epic
text: Forrest Gump still ranks among the top fifteen box office hits of all time in America, taking in over $329 million. The movie follows the journey of a slow man who gains glory and fame in a diverse and sometimes turbulent era in history. Forrest often doesn't realize the significant impact he makes on some of the most influential people in America. His true love, Jenny, represents the typical youth during that time, and constantly eludes him. They eventually marry and have a son together, but their family life is cut short when Jenny becomes suddenly ill and dies. Forrest lived a full life, inspiring those around him in many ways. As Forrest said, "I might not be a smart man, but I know what love is." The audience connects with his character, experiencing life through Forrest's eyes. The film won six Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Director and is rightly considered an epic in American culture.

title: Good
text: The moment that sunk into the soul: this is when Forest brings a letter written by their son to the grave of his beloved, and says that he did not read it, because you cannot read other people's letters ... It would seem so easy to be a decent person! And what a rarity it is in our time, when it is considered the norm that loved ones rummage through the mobile phones of their halves, looking for other people's SMS when someone else's mail is opened. How sad it all is.

title: A cult epic masterpiece
text: It seems like a story about a fool who was often lucky in life, but I think Forrest Gump is the story of an ordinary, just an oddball PURE man without problems and prejudices - a man who lived and did what he liked, even if it seemed to make no sense, a man who valued love and friendship, referring simply to material things (which, by the way, he still had), he could not sometimes stand up for himself, but could protect people close to him. After watching the film to the end and feeling every stage of this difficult life, you begin to understand that fools were around him, and not he is the fool among all.

title: A film about love
text: Forest Gump is a film that motivates, despite any difficulties, not to give up. This film is about everyone and about everything and about everyone, about love, understanding and the struggle for. The basis is sincerity. Endless love for the simplicity of the main character, who has always lived in the world with only one dream of happiness, with one state of mind. He never argued with his fate, but always went his own way, overcoming the pain. The most important thing is that he believed, he always believed in himself and in the words of his mother. He was like a ray of light for the people who were next to him at that moment and, looking at him, understood that you can discard everything bad and bad from yourself and just follow.Love for a girl is the main idea of the film, through which the whole life path of our protagonist smoothly passes. Forrest had never seen a more beautiful girl in his life than his Jenny, beloved Jenny. Forrest had always genuinely loved her, always protected her-always helped and protected her. Immediately, faith in this fate appears again, in the fact that she will still allow him to be near his beloved, with his happiness. This film teaches us to believe in ourselves and fate, sincere happiness. To love and appreciate parents. "Forest Gump" will bring you to tears and leave a pleasant impression.

title: But maybe I asked too much. Moreover, Gump is not controversial.
text: Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks) is a simple man with a sweet heart. This is his journey through American history. His childhood friend Jenny (Robin Wright) travels through the wrong side of the same world. His journey is heavily influenced by his mom (Sally Field), Lieutenant Dan (Gary Sinise), and Bubba Blue (Mykelti Williamson).Director Robert Zemeckis has added another chapter to the American myth. This is a fairy tale where the good guys win. That you can rise to the top, no matter what your flaws are. That a good heart will enlighten all whom it touches. This is a fairy tale worthy of Frank Capra.If I could make a wish, I wish Gump's journey had a deeper meaning. For example, he is given the opportunity to speak about the Vietnam War, but the sound disappears from his microphone. I'd like to hear what he had to say. But maybe I asked too much. Moreover, Gump is not controversial.

title: personal favourite
text: I do love all three films of The Lord of the Rings trilogy, all are visually stunning with wonderful music and strong narratives. The Two Towers is my personal favourite of the three for several reasons. For one thing it is less talky than Fellowship of the Ring, and the pace is a little more secure here. Also the final battle is just breathtaking in the action, direction and in its scope, and very compelling and epic. And some of the characters are developed more here than they were in Fellowship of the Ring primarily Frodo and Aragorn, who were played very well there but a little bland in comparison to here.

title: A Bit overrated

title: Perfect movie that brightened my day!
text: Forrest Gump was directed by Robert Zemeckis. And also has a well-known actor of all time, Tom Hanks. This movie has won many Oscar awards and the storyline is so catching and really shows the need of human being; "Love". All of these are portrayed through a life of a man with low IQ. It's so nice and beautiful that it gave me a peaceful mind for a week.The plot was so unique from the other movie at that time, they tell the story from a low IQ man's perspective. It really reflects how life is going, life is not just a man grow up and complete his dream, but there always has a problem. This makes the life tough and complicated, but also gives the life more meaning.There is always a beautiful lesson in each of the situations our main character 'Forrest Gump' faced. We could feel friendship, mom's love and even a marriage life. All of the character involved is deeply described in the script, it's not just telling who is bad or who is good. Everyone here seems to be human; they have reasons on their choice and that is why the plot is so profound. But it's not only profound, they combined all the historical figures and it just became humor in the movie.And for the actor, it's so amazing, they can imitate a person in each condition; their conversation, thought and behavior. It's really easy to ruin the real look of those people (I referred to all kind of people, disabled person, teenage or even soldier). But the actors still carried it out and it fits the storyline so much.Lastly, the another factor I want to share is that I know a person who has problems like Forrest Gump, they both suffered from society's misunderstood about them. And after watching this film, woww they really illustrated my friend in a film, the way they speak, their standing poses, their reaction. It just looks so real and it really lightened up my day.The message I got from this story is You don't have to be clever or fox-mind people, just be nice, gentle and kind to other people. In the film there is always a coincidence with something unpredictable and boom, it's wining lottery every month.Hope this review is useful. I really recommend this movie for those who don't know what to watch. May God bless you all.

title: one of my favorites
text: Forrest Gump is one of my all time favorite movies, not only because it's a great movie but it shows plays out many events in history. It has many morals and quotes that pertain to everyday life. For example; "Life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're gonna get." That quote is so true about life in general; you never know what is going to happen next. It's a movie that I never get tired of and can't help but to love, even if some people say that it is overrated.The only thing that I didn't like about the movie is the stretch of believing that someone with a very low IQ could accomplish so many things and randomly be a part of all the events in history that took place. I mean, I guess it could happen but it would be very unlikely.I would compare this movie to any other movie that has to do with people with disabilities, such as Radio, a movie that has to do with a complicated love story and the army such as Dear John.

title: Brilliant Movie Forrest Gump
text:
When I first watched this movie I was blown away, the 2nd time I was blown away and the 3rd the 4th the 5th etc etc. Tom Hanks lost weight and put on weight to look the part for his movies. He's truly a magnificent actor certainly one of the best in my time. I have rarely seen a movie that Tom is in that wasnt very good. My son and I always narrate parts of the movie when we feel the need to act silly and saying "You got new legs Lieutenant Dan ! Or "Sorry I ruined your New Years eve party Lieutenant Dan but she tasted like cigarettes!"
My son is now 29 and we still mess around now and then. It is truly one of the movies that everyone speaks about and a wonderful feel good 90's movie as most of the movies in the 90's were. I recommend this movie for everyone 15 and up as it is funny, entertaining, factual and just a feel good type of movie that you will want to watch at any time any era for the many eras to come, and it gets etched into your mind making you want more. Shame there wasn't a follow up though, maybe one day.

title: A must-see classic movie!!
text: I believe that Forrest Gump had the criteria for a great movie including its plot, characters, rating, and graphics. The plot is one everyone can relate to. The plot consists of someone not fitting in and breaking through the standards that people placed on him and finding his true love. The actors that are playing these roles could not have been more perfect. Forrest is an average man with a very low IQ but he has an optimistic view of the world. Tom Hanks plays Forrest and he plays it well. Along with Mykelti Williamson playing Forrest's very good friend Bubba Blue. There are many actors and characters in the movie, but every role was successfully played out to its full potential. The rating on this site is an 8.7 out of 10. This rating is an accurate one because it reflects not just what one or two people think of it, but a multitude of people. The movie won six academy awards including best picture. An 8.7 is a good rating, it could be even higher for the amount of awards it got and how many people loved it. The graphics, for when the film was made, were great. The war scenes, the presidential scenes, and the segment with Elvis Presley and all the other famous characters, were portrayed well. It made the movie seem less fictional and more relatable. With the great plot, awesome characters, accurate rating, and exciting graphics, the movie Forrest Gump is a must-see.

title: A majestic piece of film
text: This is without a doubt one of my best films of all time. It's just a masterpiece to behold in my eyes and i'll tell you why: The acting is superb, Tom hanks really is Forrest Gump in this film to every minute detail. Robin Wright Penn is also sensational in this film. She just brings tears to my eyes her final scene. She really comes of ' age ' in this film. She portrays every painful experience of Jenny in such depth but equally can highlight on the more peaceful and content side of the troubled girl. Finally Sally Fields is class through and through in this film. She's such a dominant actress on screen and she always delivers. Her line to Forrest when she's on her deathbed is so poignant and heartbreaking. ' I will miss you Forrest '. It just was spellbinding to watch such great actors come together in this film. Absolutely superb.Finally, the use of historical events and the way they fit around Forest is just superb, i've never seen anything so creative and intuitive. From John Lennon, Elvis, Nixon and Lennon, this really establishes an almost reality that Forrest Gump is a influential part of American society.My final words are WATCH THIS FILM!! This is truly cinema at its best.

title: a great actor doesn't mean a great movie
text: Tom Hanks plays a young southern boy in this sort of coming of age movie. The story starts as Forrest (tom hanks) goes from being a "below average intellect" child with walking disabilities. Right from the start, Forrest overcomes challenges that are seemingly impossible, just to name one. He later makes a friend Jenny who he soon becomes inseparable from. Forrest grows up, becomes a star football player in his college and enlists in the army to go to Vietnam. While in the war he rescues his commanding officer Lt. Dan and receives the Medal of Honor, which was awarded by JFK. Upon coming home, he reunites with his long lost, and now hippie, Jenny. He falls in love with her, only for her to run off with an anti military friend. Forrest, feeling lost, starts a shrimp catching business which becomes the best around. Later he finds out that Jenny was impregnated with his son and they marry. Soon after Jenny dies. The story makes you have many different feelings at times, mostly good, but I believe there are too many times Forrest had overcame these challenges. Sure, people overcome some incredible odds at times but I think there were too many thrown into the plot. The story comes off as far fetched most of the time but it doesn't really ruin the movie. Overall, it's a good movie. Don't get me wrong. The movie just isn't as good as people want it to be.

title: Great Movie
text: I loved it the first and second time I watched it. Tom Hanks really nailed the roll of the "Slow- witted" American that he played. A Beautiful movie that can show how despite our imperfections we can still live very active and exciting lives as Forest Gump does and that "life is like a box of chocolates" as Forest's mum said.
